awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Predicting the Observational Appearance of Accreting Black Holes
awd_abstract_narration:
Since black holes are by definition invisible, the only way that astronomers can detect them is by observing material accreting onto (or falling into) the black hole.   Given the strong gravity, intense radiation and powerful magnetic fields near black holes, it is not surprising that such accretion is complex and can only be understood by running sophisticated numerical models on supercomputers.  A research collaboration between the University of Illinois, Princeton University and the University of California-Berkeley will model the behavior of black-hole accretion in the realm intermediate between strong and weak accretion, when interesting effects such as jets of outflowing material and unusual oscillations in the accretion are known to take place.  This work will help to unravel mysteries related to black holes, such as how the jets form and how the structure of the accretion flow changes over time.  The team will communicate the excitement of black-hole astrophysics to the public through lectures and visualizations and to future generations of students through a black hole summer school.

The theory of black-hole (BH) accretion and outflows is central to many areas of modern astrophysics and gravitational physics. The collaboration team has developed numerical techniques that permit nearly ab initio modeling of black-hole accretion in both the high- and low-accretion-rate limits. The team plans to develop new numerical techniques and codes suitable for studying the difficult intermediate-accretion-rate regime, which is associated with jets, quasi-periodic oscillations, and state transitions around stellar-mass black holes. Additions to the models include radiation forces, pair production and transport, nonthermal particle production and transport, and collisionless plasma effects, all of which are critical for making progress on long-standing problems in black-hole astrophysics, such as the structure and observational appearance (spectrum, time variability, polarization) of accretion at intermediate accretion rates, as well as questions about the origin and maintenance of large-scale magnetic fields believed to power relativistic jets from such systems.   The group will make their new codes available for others to use through public releases.

por.por_cntn:
In Einstein's theory of gravity, black holes are objects that have
collapsed completely under their own gravity.  We now know that
black holes with mass much larger than the Sun inhabit the center of
most galaxies, including our own Milky Way.  Gas falling toward
these supermassive black holes heats up and produces radiation
across the electromagnetic spectrum, from radio waves to gamma-rays.
The radiation carries information about the black hole's mass, how
rapidly it is spinning, and about how it interacts with the
surrounding hot gas.

In this grant, which supported a collaboration between Illinois,
Berkeley, and Princeton, we developed and applied techniques for
modeling and predicting the radio, millimeter, infrared, and x-ray
radiation from black holes.  As part of this work we produced
computer models used to physically interpret Event Horizon
Telescope's landmark first image, in 2019, of the black hole in the
galaxy M87 2019, the first polarized image, in 2021, of the black
hole in M87, and the first image, in 2022, of the galactic center
black hole.

The modeling of Event Horizon Telescope sources was a major success.
Models produced by the PI's group explain nearly all of the observed
features of the black hole in M87 and the black hole in the galactic
center.  For both black holes the models were crucial in estimating
the mass of the black hole and in assessing the accuracy of the
measurement.  

In the future Event Horizon Telescope will make movies of black
holes.  The PI and his group, in work performed under this grant,
predict that these movies will show slowly circulating, ingoing
waves.  The properties of these waves depend on the black hole mass,
spin, and orientation.  Measurement of the wave speeds in future
movies, therefore, is expected to provide information about black
hole spin.

An additional focus of this work was how radiation from gas flows
around black holes interacts with the gas itself.  For example, we
studied a component of the radiation field produced by a process
called bremsstrahlung, which can produce x-rays and gamma-rays.  We
showed that the gamma-rays collide with each other and produce
matter and antimatter (so-called electron-positron pairs), and that
near the black hole in M87 this process can provide a background of
conducting plasma that shorts out any electric fields produced by
the motion of the gas.

This grant had broader impacts through communication of exciting
science to the public, through communication of new developments to
researchers, and through training of students and postdocs.
The PI gave 21 public talks, 17 interviews, and 31 professional
talks during the funding period.  The PI also mentored 13
undergraduates, 10 graduate students, and 1 postdoc during the
funding period.
